title: 115_s720
content: The Act may be cited as the "Israel Anti-Boycott Act" and includes findings. The United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) has systematically targeted Israel with politically motivated assaults on its legitimacy, including calls for a commercial boycott and the establishment of a blacklist of companies operating beyond Israel's 1949 Armistice lines. The UNHRC is considering a resolution to withhold assistance and prevent trade with territories occupied since 1967, including East Jerusalem, the West Bank, and the Golan Heights. Businesses operating in these areas could face legal action. Congress has a history of combating anti-Israel boycotts under various acts and agreements. The recent action of the UNHRC is similar to the Arab League Boycott, targeting companies trading with Israel. Congress passed anti-boycott measures in trade agreements. The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 opposes actions to boycott, divest from, or sanction Israel, requires the US to use trade negotiations against such actions, and mandates reporting on foreign barriers to trade with Israel. The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 opposes actions against Israel and mandates reporting on foreign trade barriers with Israel. Congress opposes the UN Human Rights Council resolution urging countries to pressure companies to divest from Israel, views it as a boycott, and encourages implementation of the US-Israel Strategic Partnership Act for cooperation in civilian areas. Technological cooperation in civilian areas such as energy, water, agriculture, alternative fuel, space technology, and security is encouraged. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO FOREIGN BOYCOTTS UNDER EXPORT ADMINISTRATION ACT OF 1979. The Export Administration Act of 1979 prohibits restrictive trade practices or boycotts imposed by foreign countries or international organizations against the US or US persons. The Export Administration Act of 1979 prohibits restrictive trade practices or boycotts imposed by foreign countries or international organizations against the US or US persons. The act also prohibits any actions that further or support such practices or boycotts against countries friendly to the US or US persons. The Export Administration Act of 1979 prohibits foreign boycotts against the US or US persons. Amendments include prohibiting requests for boycotts by foreign countries. The Export Administration Act of 1979 prohibits foreign boycotts against the US or US persons, including requests for boycotts by foreign countries or international governmental organizations against Israel. The Export Administration Act of 1979 prohibits foreign boycotts against the US or US persons, including requests for boycotts by foreign countries or international governmental organizations against Israel. Amendments include inserting language to address restrictive trade practices or boycotts by foreign countries and international governmental organizations against Israel. Amendments to the Export Administration Act of 1979 address violations of Section 8(a) and define International Governmental Organization. Amendments to the Export Administration Act of 1979 include redefining the term 'international governmental organization' to include the United Nations and the European Union. The amendments take effect upon enactment and are implemented through the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. SEC. 5 amends the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 to prohibit policies that target Israel for commercial limitations. SEC. 6 provides definitions. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms like "actions to boycott, divest from, or sanction Israel," "international governmental organization," and "politically motivated." Nothing in this section should change the established policy of the United States. The curr_chunk states that no actions should be taken to change the established policy of the United States regarding final status issues in the Arab-Israeli conflict, which can only be resolved through direct negotiations between the parties.
